pr_title: DS-4061 expose sitemaps and schedule automatic updates

timeline.bodyText: Because this endpoint is hardcoded in two places (here and in the Controller), I'd prefer that we move this to a configuration key in dspace.cfg.  You could call it sitemap.path = sitemaps   (As that would be similar to oai.path in oai.cfg and sword-server.path in sword-server.cfg), and place it next to the existing sitemap.dir setting in dspace.cfg
timeline.author: tdonohue

timeline.bodyText: I'm a little torn on these changes.  The Handles should still work here (as we still support Handles)...but a redirection is needed to the /communities path, /collections path, etc.  Is there a specific reason you chose to remove the Handles from the sitemap?
timeline.author: tdonohue

replies.bodyText:
At this point in time, they don't work. This can be reverted if the handles work, but I'd prefer to have a working solution
I also thought there were plans to remove the requirement to have a handle (so it would become optional)
replies.author: benbosman

replies.bodyText: @benbosman : aha, ok. I didn't realize these were not working.  I'm OK with this change, I was mostly asking the reason why it was made.  I do feel handles will be made optional eventually, so you are correct this is a step in that direction.  I'll close out this request as resolved. Thanks!

timeline.bodyText:
is this what we really expect/want?
I would suggest to return a forbidden or a not found. The first is preferred in my opinion as it should also whom is more concerned about security to track this devil request for further analysis.
timeline.author: abollini

replies.bodyText:
I agree, this seems like it should be throwing a ResourceNotFoundException (or maybe responding with a simple 404 response code, i.e. .andExpect(status().isNotFound()); ) based on the code in SitemapRestController here: https://github.com/DSpace/DSpace/pull/2858/files#diff-be5a61ded7d68e1169e3c3576ca9ce30R93
If that's not possible (for some reason), we could leave this as-is & add either a TODO or bug ticket. As-is, this test does prove that you cannot access other files from this endpoint, but the @Test(expected=ServletException.class) just seems like the wrong response.
In debugging this, we could add an additional simplistic test here to ensure an invalid filename (something like "notasitemap.html") also throws a ResourceNotFoundException or 404 response.
replies.author: tdonohue

replies.bodyText:
This is valid behavior because it's an attempt to bypass security. The message returned is also: The request was rejected because the URL contained a potentially malicious String "%2e"
For non-attacks, just incorrect filenames, 404 is returned instead
replies.author: benbosman

replies.bodyText: I'm OK with this for now. If we later decide to improve on it, we can do so. The bigger point is that this sort of request should throw an error & it obviously does. Thanks @benbosman
